newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Racehorse on experimental human fertility programme.
newsitem.headline: Racehorse on experimental human fertility programme.

text.p: A US$2 million champion stallion in New Zealand has been put on an experimental fertility programme previously used on human males after failing to match his racecourse success on the stud farm.
Maroof was a cut above most of his opposition on the European racing scene, but managed just 22 successes in 65 attempts as a sire, the New Zealand Press Association reported on Tuesday.
It cost NZ$27,500 (US$20,000) every time he failed to deliver.
Now, Maroof is being tried on a revolutionary fertility programme under the control of Auckland University.
Cambridge Stud owner Patrick Hogan is buoyed by an improved mare pregnancy success rate of eight from 13 servings by Maroof this year.
"It is entirely experimental and has never been tried on a horse before. He is under a similar programme to that used on human males with fertility problems," Hogan said.
"It is early days, but those results have given us a great lift and we are very satisfied with them."
Hogan would not disclose details of the treatment due to commercial sensitivity, but said the course helped the horse's sperm to mature.
On the track, Maroof was the champion European four-year-old in 1994 and won the group one Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Royal Ascot, England.
